document_content.title: Referral to Cardiology for Evaluation of Chest Discomfort

sections.heading: Reason for Referral
sections.content: Ms. Jane Doe is being referred to your cardiology service for further evaluation of intermittent chest discomfort and palpitations that have persisted over the past two months.

sections.heading: History of Present Illness
sections.content: The patient reports experiencing episodes of central chest pressure, typically lasting 5â€“10 minutes, often occurring during moderate exertion such as climbing stairs. She describes the discomfort as non-radiating and not associated with shortness of breath, diaphoresis, or syncope. She notes occasional palpitations but denies dizziness or presyncope. There is no clear relation to meals or emotional stress.

sections.heading: Past Medical History
sections.content: No known history of hypertension, diabetes, or hyperlipidemia. No prior cardiac events. Family history is notable for coronary artery disease in her father (diagnosed at age 58). Non-smoker. No current medications.

sections.heading: Assessment
sections.content: Ms. Doe presents with exertional chest discomfort and palpitations in the absence of significant cardiac risk factors. Physical examination and baseline ECG in our clinic were unremarkable. Given her symptoms and family history, further cardiac evaluation is warranted to rule out underlying ischemic heart disease or arrhythmia.

sections.heading: Plan
sections.content: Referral to cardiology for further assessment, including consideration of exercise stress testing and Holter monitoring. Please advise regarding additional management or investigations as appropriate. The patient has been advised to avoid strenuous activity until further evaluation.
